p: According to results of our literature review, M. lycopodioides has been studied and mentioned in a total of 63 journal articles over the past 60â€‰years. However, the vast majority of these papers deal with non-medicinal use and are not part of drug discovery-related research. The papers mainly describe the occurrence of the fern species in the American tropical forests and its extraordinary morphology/biology; traditional medicinal use has only been mentioned in two publications so far. Here, it has been reported to be used for removal of lice and to treat anemia in South Africa and Tanzania [ 56]. The second publication reports traditional use by the Zambo-Miskito ethnic group of Eastern Nicaragua to cure bewitchment and chase away evil spirits [ 57].
